title: Here are the 63 Republicans who voted against the anti-Asian hate crimes bill
body: Here are the 63 Republicans who voted against the anti-Asian hate crimes billBy Devan Cole, CNNUpdated 4:47 PM ET, Thu May 20, 2021 JUST WATCHEDStudy finds anti-Asian hate crimes surging in 2021ReplayMore Videos ...MUST WATCH (17 Videos)Study finds anti-Asian hate crimes surging in 2021Israel and Hamas agree to ceasefire Local politicians seen at Capitol riot still in high power positionsBiden gets passionate during speech on anti-Asian hate crime billBBC issues apology for 1995 Princess Diana interviewFirst tropical system of the Atlantic hurricane season is likely to form this weekendWatch the moment the House passes bill to create January 6 commissionVideo: 11-year-old girl fights off abductor at bus stopJoe Biden singles out Russia and China in commencement addressBitcoin plunges as China's crypto crackdown widensMcConnell: I made my views about January 6 very clearBody-cam video in shooting of Andrew Brown Jr. shown to public for the first time New York Gov. Graham on election claimsFormer CIA officer describes experience with mysterious illness6-year-old airstrike survivor pulled from rubble'Exasperated': GOP Arizona election official reacts to Trump's election lieWashington (CNN)When the House on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved legislation intended to counter a rise in anti-Asian hate crimes amid the coronavirus pandemic, 62 GOP members voted against the measure, which was also opposed by one Republican senator when it cleared that chamber last month. The bill, which is likely to be signed by President Joe Biden, would create a new position at the Justice Department to expedite review of potential Covid-19-related hate crimes and incidents reported at the federal, state or local level. It would also direct the departments of Justice and Health and Human Services to work with community-based organizations to issue guidance raising awareness of hate crimes during the pandemic, and would require the US attorney general to issue guidance to work with state and local law enforcement agencies to establish online reporting of them.The lone Republican senator to oppose the measure in April was Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, who said at the time that his opposition stemmed from what he called "big free speech questions."
